thread.title: AFC Asian Cup: Aymen Hussein double helps Iraq stun four-time winner Japan - Sportstar
thread.title_full: AFC Asian Cup: Aymen Hussein double helps Iraq stun four-time winner Japan - Sportstar

author: Neeladri Bhattacharjee
title: AFC Asian Cup: Aymen Hussein double helps Iraq stun four-time winner Japan - Sportstar
text:
Football has a fickle memory. It thrives in the present and often, changes for a better future.
That was what Japan coach Hajime Moriyasu had suggested in the pre-match press conference before its clash against Iraq in the AFC Asian Cup 2023, at the Education City Stadium on Friday.
The last time Japan played Iraq in Qatar, a 2-2 draw at the Jassim bin Hamad Stadium in 1993 had broken dreams of playing its maiden FIFA World Cup. ‚ÄúMost of the players in the current squad were not even born when the match was played,‚Äù Moriyasu had said, ‚Äúthat game is past now.‚Äù
But ghastly memories of that three-decade-old match came back to haunt the Samurai Blue as Iraq rode on raucous fan support and clinical attacking to beat Japan 2-1 in its second group-stage game.
Both goals came off Aymen Hussein‚Äôs head, who was subbed off at half-time in what looked like a problem in his right hamstring.
ALSO READ: South Korea keeper Kim ruled out of competition with knee injury
This was the first win since 1982 for the Central Asian side against the four-time Asian champion when it had beaten Japan 1-0 at the Asian Games.
Iraq created overloads in Japan‚Äôs half right from kick-off, mirroring Japan‚Äôs start against Vietnam in its first game. In that match, Moriyasu‚Äôs side had opened the scoring within 11 minutes.
Iraq, under Jesus Garcia, drew first blood even quicker.
In the fifth minute, Ahmed Yahya Al-Hajjaj‚Äôs through ball was received by Ali Jasim Elaibi on the left flank, who put his foot on the gas to maraud along the left flank and deliver a cross.
Though Zion Suzuki, Japan‚Äôs goalkeeper, pushed the ball out, it fell for Aymen Hussein, who headed the ball in causing an eruption of joy in the stadium.
The 38,663 fans at the stadium, most of whom were Iraqi, made the air crackle with Viking claps, regional songs and chants of ‚ÄúIraq!‚Äù and made sure a trailing Japan remained on the backfoot with whistles and boos every time it had the ball.
